Award.AwardTitle: GP-IMPACT: Increasing Diversity and Enhancing Academia (IDEA-2.0): Institutionalizing a framework for broadening participation in geosciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Institute for the Environment at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC-IE) and the Department of Environmental, Earth and Geospatial Sciences at North Carolina Central University (NCCU-DEEGS) are implementing a three-year initiative - Increasing Diversity and Enhancing Academia-2.0, or IDEA-2.0 - to broaden participation in and institutional capacity to offer career-relevant geoscience education at both institutions. Through research and professional experiences, a diverse group of undergraduate students is being prepared for future work in geoscience fields. Additionally, their supervisors are being better prepared to mentor diverse students, improving recruitment and retention in geosciences. IDEA-2.0 represents a coordinated effort between a research-intensive university and a historically black university to bolster participation in geoscience education, especially the participation of URM and women students. The institutionalization of existing, informal partnerships is building a foundation for ongoing support of evidence-based, career-relevant geoscience experiences for undergraduates while also better preparing faculty to mentor diverse students. Additional partners in this effort include the following geoscience departments at UNC-Chapel Hill: Environmental Sciences and Engineering, Geography, Geology, Marine Sciences and the Curriculum for the Environment and Ecology. Over time, it is anticipated that the combination of sustained professional development opportunities for students combined with enhanced preparation of mentors will contribute to cultural shifts within institutions that are likely to promote greater diversity in geoscience disciplines and the workforce. Thus, this project serves the national interest by promoting the progress of science and advancing the national health, prosperity and welfare.

The IDEA-2.0 program has a goal of broadening participation in and institutional capacity to offer career-relevant geoscience education at UNC-Chapel Hill and North Carolina Central University, while generating useful insights into how such practices could be implemented successfully at other institutions. Program goals are being accomplished through the following objectives: 1. Engage up to 30 students - including underrepresented minority (URM) and women students - in evidence-based, career-relevant experiences that prepare them for work or further study in geosciences; 2. Prepare a subset of faculty, postdoctoral scholars and graduate students to mentor a diverse group of students and contribute to broad understanding of how the mentoring experience influences recruitment and retention in the geosciences pipeline; and 3. Build capacity to sustain coordinated programming across departments at UNC-Chapel Hill and to fund and implement new programming at NCCU. By targeting students who are rising sophomores and juniors, IDEA-2.0 focuses on the critical juncture between high school and commitment to undergraduate geoscience programs. The first two years of undergraduate study are a critical time to recruit/retain STEM majors; early engagement in research has been shown to contribute to institutional-level success in engaging URM students in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Mentoring interactions also have been shown to reinforce students' confidence in their ability to succeed and are associated with higher grades in STEM courses, higher rates of degree completion, and, for STEM-focused recruitment and retention programs, with participants' ultimate pursuit of science careers. For these reasons, IDEA-2.0 seeks to engage mentors in an ongoing cycle of professional development that prepares them to meet the mentorship needs of diverse students. The explicit focus of this project is on understanding the mentoring relationship - both its influence on student career and academic choices as well as faculty confidence and competence in supporting diverse teams - contributing to our understanding of how to effectively foster diversity in STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Increasing Diversity and Enhancing Academia 2.0 program (IDEA 2.0) was to broaden participation in geosciences by increasing capacity to provide mentored research experiences in geoscience departments at The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC-CH) and in the Department of Environment, Earth and Geospatial Sciences at North Carolina Central University (NCCU-DEEGS). The major activity supported by this program was the provision of high-quality geoscience research experiences for undergraduate students. Other essential components included: (a) evaluation of the role of mentoring in successful research experiences and preparation of faculty/graduate student mentors to support diverse undergraduates, (b) infrastructure to support ongoing programming at UNC-CH, and (c) new geoscience programming at NCCU.

Over the funding period (2016-2020), IDEA 2.0 supported four cohorts, with 37 total students. Almost 90% (33 students) identified with one or more groups that are underrepresented in STEM, with 68% (25) being female. About 24% (9) identified as Black/African-American students and 19% (7) as Hispanic/Latino students. Four students identified with two or more racial/ethnic groups. These cohorts of students were significant as an element of a more inclusive research environment on the UNC-CH campus and because students became a support and resource network for one another. Across program years, the leadership team increased both the application rate for NCCU-DEEGS students and the percentage of NCCU-DEEGS students that comprised each cohort. These increases resulted from enhanced recruitment efforts and creation of a modified, parallel application process, providing insight into how tailored recruitment and application processes can generate a larger pool of qualified applicants from groups that are underrepresented in STEM.

For students from both UNC-CH and NCCU-DEEGS, IDEA 2.0 provided experiences that helped them to envision themselves as future scientists and to develop professional skills and networks that will support them in their careers. For a subset, IDEA 2.0 was a foundational experience that encouraged them to continue their geoscience education. About 54% (20) participated in additional geoscience or STEM research and field experiences, and 13 participated in formal geoscience internships after IDEA 2.0. Six of these were REUs, with organizations that included the US Geological Survey, the US Army Corps of Engineers, the Smithsonian Institution, and oceanographic research institutes. Additionally, about 49% (18) of the students reported current or planned enrollment in advanced degrees in geoscience or STEM disciplines. 

IDEA 2.0 also resulted in several important institutional-level outcomes at UNC-CH, both within geosciences departments and across the University, including development of a stronger network to recruit and retain diverse students and a commitment to support the development of welcoming and inclusive cultures within labs and departments. In 2020, IDEA 2.0 program staff joined colleagues in the UNC School of Medicine and the NCCU College of Health Sciences to launch a new internship program, funded by the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, that supports year-long environmental health sciences research experiences for students who are underrepresented in STEM. IDEA 2.0 has also created a pipeline for community college students to participate in geoscience research at UNC-CH through a new program that provides students from Robeson Community College with summer research internships at UNC-CH. This program was launched in 2019 by IDEA 2.0 program staff and is supported by the Burroughs Wellcome Fund. IDEA 2.0 staff advised UNC Marine Sciences and its affiliated coastal research center in their diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts, including developing a unified mechanism for recruiting underrepresented students and matching them with mentors/labs that provide inclusive research experiences. Additionally, IDEA 2.0 program staff supported the UNC-CH Chancellor's Science Scholars Program in incorporating geosciences into its programming. 

Significant outcomes for NCCU-DEEGS included development of a new geoscience degree program, a GEOPATHS IMPACT award from NSF, and new geoscience enrichment opportunities. Specifically, NCCU- DEEGS was approved to offer an Accelerated Bachelor?s/Master?s (ABM) Program, in which students complete a B.S. in Environmental and Geographic Science and an M.S. in Earth Science in five years. The first cohort of ABM students continued to the MS program in January 2020 and were expected to complete their Master?s degrees in December 2020. NCCU-DEEGS also received a three-year GEOPATHS-IMPACT award to create sustainable partnerships with two North Carolina community colleges: Carteret Community College and Alamance Community College. Finally, during IDEA 2.0, NCCU-DEEGS developed several new enrichment experiences for undergraduates including 2-week summer research courses.

In summary, the IDEA 2.0 program served as an integral component of a community that is transforming the geosciences into a field that draws on and values the experience and knowledge of all people. The IDEA 2.0 leadership team actively created opportunities for students and mentors to consider issues of inclusion and representation in their work, in the hope that greater understanding of inequity in the geosciences, and STEM fields generally, would lead to individual and institutional changes that foster equity.
